Dawn Turner Trice of the Chicago Tribune started a blog in response to Senator Barack Obama's call for a national dialogue on race.

It's an open forum for people of all backgrounds to discuss their experiences about race, and she joins us now from the studio in Chicago, where she's a columnist for the Tribune, and mediates a blog called ""Exploring Race."" Dawn Turner Trice, nice to have you on the program today.
Thank you so much.
And I wonder, do you get blogs - do you get posts on your blog, that go to the gut level, do you think?
Oh, absolutely.
When we started this back -, actually I had the idea back in January, right after Obama won the Iowa caucuses.
I mean, we all, clearly, were very surprised that you have a man of color that did so well in a state that is overwhelmingly white.
And I just - I thought that there had to have been something going on in the country.
I know that racism is not dead, but we were trying to just explore some of the models for race that we've held dear for many years.
And so we started - the actual blog started after - a couple of days after the speech, the Philadelphia speech that Obama gave on race.
And one of the things that I said from the very, very beginning, that it was so important to have people speak openly and honestly about race.
And it's something that we don't, definitely politicians - I mean, clearly tap dance around it all the time.
And especially at the presidential level, they don't necessarily talk about race.
They don't have to.
And it's a third-rail issue, so why do it?
But on our forum, we wanted to have people - we wanted this to be a safe place where people could speak openly and honestly.
We didn't want just people preaching to the choir, or we didn't want it to be an echo chamber.
We've seen enough of those.
We wanted this to be something different.
And so far, we've had a diversity of comments.
And I wonder, does the anonymity, or relative anonymity, of a blog, do you think, foster this dialogue?
It absolutely does.
People feel free to say things that they would not ordinarily say in face-to-face contact.
And some of the comments are reflective of that, because they could be very, very - they're biting at times.
But there is no way that you can separate that.
If you want to have an open discussion, you can't say, well, you can say this but you can't say that.
Now we will take out certain words, maybe the N-word or something like that, but I will, if the word is written out, I'll just make it the N-word.
I want it to be - I want people - we need to see all of this.
For too long, I think, it's been just kind of hidden, and it's been allowed to fester.
Or people will talk about it in homogenous company.
But I like the idea of everybody getting a sense of the good, and the not so good.
